hedline.hl1: For Escalators and Elevators, Newer Isn't Better, Report Says

abstract.p: Dozens of new subway elevators and escalators installed during last six years at cost of more than $500 million have been breaking down more often than system's older elevators and escalators (M)

block.p: Dozens of new subway elevators and escalators installed during the last six years at a cost of more than $500 million have been breaking down more often than the system's older elevators and escalators, an examination by the public advocate's office has found.

Researchers for the public advocate drew their results from New York City Transit's own reliability figures for the 73 elevators and 178 escalators in place throughout the subway system. The researchers found that the 32 elevators installed since 1994 were out of service for an average of 28 days between May 1999 and April 2000. Older ones were broken for an average of 16 days during the same period.

Dozens of new subway elevators and escalators installed during the last six years at a cost of more than $500 million have been breaking down more often than the system's older elevators and escalators, an examination by the public advocate's office has found.

Researchers for the public advocate drew their results from New York City Transit's own reliability figures for the 73 elevators and 178 escalators in place throughout the subway system. The researchers found that the 32 elevators installed since 1994 were out of service for an average of 28 days between May 1999 and April 2000. Older ones were broken for an average of 16 days during the same period.
For escalators, the 70 installed since 1994 were out of service for an average of 26 days during the 1999-2000 period, while older ones were down for 22 days during that time.
The study excluded shutdowns caused by replacement, rehabilitation, preventive maintenance and vandalism.
Mark J. Green, the public advocate, announced the findings yesterday, and called on transit officials to provide an explanation.
''It's very troubling because of how many elderly and disabled and parents with strollers are dependent on this transportation to the transportation,'' Mr. Green said.

Transit officials said the study did not credit the agency for adding more elevators and escalators in recent years. The study also masked the fact that overall reliability of the machinery has been improving, they added. Those escalators that were not being rehabilitated or replaced were available 94.5 percent of the time during the first six months of this year, said Al O'Leary, a spokesman for the transit agency. Elevators that were not taken out service for rehabilitation or replacement were available 97.5 percent of the time, he added.
Transit officials said the study reflected only that the newer equipment was more technically complex, requiring additional time to work out bugs after being installed.

''That would be credible if we were just looking at machinery that had been installed in the last year or very recently,'' said Joseph Rappaport, Mr. Green's transit adviser. ''But we're looking at things that have been in place for years.''
